projectDesc.p: The Greenfield Digital Project interprets the story of Bankers Trust Company, a large Philadelphia bank that failed in 1930, through a selection of primary source documents, contextual essays, and teacher resources. The project is part of a larger effort funded by the Albert M. Greenfield Foundation to make HSP's 20th-century holdings more accessible.

div.p: FRANCIS S. GOGLIA, ASST. TRUST OFFICER
C. HERBERT SCHALL, ASST. TRUST OFFICER

div.opener: July 1st. 1930. Mr. Albert M. Greenfield, 310 W. Johnson Street, Germantown, Phila.Writing to Greenfield at his home rather than his business address, Reeve appears to be soliciting Greenfield as a potential customer, though he certainly would have known of Greenfield's professional involvement in Bankers Trust. Dear Mr. Greenfield:
div.p: The Trust Department of your Company has, in the past two years, grown from nothing to over $2,500,000. and has many millions of future business in its vaults. In these results are included business from only five of our thirty-seven directors.

We, in the management, feel that the Trust Department can be of real service to you, either immediately or in the future, and see no reason why you should hesitate to entrust your affairs to the Company.

The writer would like very much to have the opportunity of discussing personally with you the many ways in which the Trust Department can serve you. An interview in the near future would be appreciated.Greenfield replied on July 16, 1930.
div.closer: Very truly yours, M E Reeve Trust Officer.
